subject: Re: [junit] Hi All
msgSnippet: It s a great question and there are lots of great answers. I think the benefits of a similar approach are going to be most obvious when working within a team.
messageBody:
It's a great question and there are lots of great
answers. I think the benefits of a similar approach
are going to be most obvious when working within a
team. Remember, we're looking to reduce code-ownership
so we have to write clear, standard code. If
developers were all off writing their own types of
tests that got executed in different ways then when i
was assigned the task of working on your work units
not only would i have to figure out "what" i would
also have to spend time on "how".

So, even if you dont use JUnit if you're working in a
group you will need to enforce/recommend some sort of
standards around unit testing your code and you'll
find when you do this that there is much similiarity
among your tests so you may as well abstract that to a
base class so that you're not duplicating
effort...hey, we're building a framework...why build
it? You need it. It exists (JUnit) and the price is
right (free).

I guess i am saying you dont NEED to use JUnit. You're
absolutely right...you can write your own tests in a
plain class...but there are many advantages to a
structured approach to unit testing and the guys that
developed JUnit were pretty smart and have thought of
most of the components of unit testing for us. So why
not take advantage?

Patrick
